sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: The aim of this document is to provide a small description of the file management system that has been developed for our Ivy RIAs applications. This file management system eases the integration of File exchange, communication, edition and creation in your Ivy RIAs applications.

sect1.title: File management system overview
sect1.para: The file management system is a set of Java Classes, Ivy Data Classes and Rich Dialogs that interoperates to be able to perform actions on files located on a Server File System or in a database just as they were located on the user's computer. You will find all those rich dialogs under ch.ivyteam.ivy.ivyaddons.filemanager.

ns:warning.para: The File Management System needs Java 6 at client side as a prerequisite.

sect1.para: The Users are then going to share the same files among an application. They will be able to edit, print, copy, zip or download those files. They will also be able to upload some Files from their computer to the server.

The file management system doesn't work with Ivy File Objects. It works with java.io.File objects and moreover with ch.ivyteam.ivy.addons.filemanager.DocumentOnServer Objects. A DocumentOnServer is just a DataClass representing a java.io.File within the file management system and contains some informations like the File size, a short description, the date and time of creation and last modification or if it is already edited (locked) by someone.

sect1.title: The FileManager RDC
sect1.para: The FileManager Rich Dialog is the most important Rich Dialog of the file management system.

It is visually composed by two main areas: a menu at the top and a split pane at the bottom. The split pane is divided in two regions: the folder explorer (RTree) and a RTable that lists the files contained into the selected folder. The top level Folder is given in the start method of the Filemanager Rich Dialog. The user cannot see the files and directories over this directory. The table displays some informations about the files: the name, the size, the Ivy User who created the File (by upload or by copy), the date and time of creation). It shows also in a tool tip the Ivy User who has last modified the file. It also shows a little Lock as icon if the file is currently edited, with the Ivy User name who is working with the file. If the user opens a file that is already edited by a third person, his changes are not going to be kept.
All those files' informations are stored in a database.

sect2.title: FileManager RDC Initialization
sect2.para: This section describes how to start and use the FileManager.

ns:warning.para: The ivy users must have at least the two following rights: ExternalDatabaseConfigurationReadMaxConnections and ExternalDatabaseConfigurationReadDatabaseConnectionConfiguration

sect2.para: There are two major informations to provide the FileManager: the server path representing the top directory that will be displayed, and the database informations to be able to retrieve the files informations.

sect3.title: The Server path
sect3.para: The server path is provided as parameter in the start methods of the RDC. This parameter can be an empty String. In such a case nothing is going to be displayed and the user will not be able to do anything. You can set the server Path dynamically at a delayed time with the setServerPath(String _serverPath) method.

If you provide a path like "Test/dir1/", the directories and theirs files are going to be located at the root of the Ivy Server installation directory. If the path is like "/test/dir1/...", the directories and theirs files are going to be located at the root of the drive. You can also provide a path like "C:/test/...".
You can connect to a file share server path with for example "//ServerShareName/dir1/". In such a case the file sharing must be configured so that the Ivy Server User can connect to it.

sect4.title: The files are stored on a server File System
sect4.para: You can use the IvySystem DB to store the informations on the files, or you can use an external Database System.

If your table is located on the Ivy System Database you just have initialize the FileManager with its startWithServerPathAndUseIvySystemDB(String _serverPath) start method. It is the easiest way to use the FileManager.

If you use an external database you have to provide more informations:
First you have to configure an Ivy Database Configuration in your project (see the Ivy Documentation related to this point).
The Table that is going to keep the informations about the files has to be created with the following SQL CREATE Statement:
CREATE TABLE uploadedfiles ( FileId INT NOT NULL AUTO_INCREMENT, FileName VARCHAR(255) NOT NULL, FilePath VARCHAR(750) NOT NULL, CreationUserId VARCHAR (200) NULL, CreationDate VARCHAR (10) NULL, CreationTime VARCHAR (8) NULL, FileSize VARCHAR (20) NULL, Locked TINYINT NULL, LockingUserId VARCHAR (200) NULL, ModificationUserId VARCHAR (200) NULL, ModificationDate VARCHAR (10) NULL, ModificationTime VARCHAR (8) NULL, Description VARCHAR(1024) NULL, PRIMARY KEY(FileId) );
Please adapt this query to your db engine.
If you run your database engine on a case sensitive system, please make sure that the column names are written in camel case (first letter of each word in uppercase, ex: FileName). In older versions of the FileManager the recommended case was the uppercase for the whole names. If you use a table from a previous version on such a case sensitive system, please rename your table's column names with the right camel case.
Then use one of the following start methods:

ns:warning.para: For the moment only three kinds of external databases were tested: MS SQL, MySQL and PostGRESQL. It should work fine with others DB Engines.

sect2.title: Other Informations on the FileManager RDC

listitem.para: The first thing to keep in mind is that when a user is editing a File, nobody else can edit it at the mean time. To unlock the file after edition the user has to unlock it manually with the "unlock" button:
After unlocking the file, if the file is still opened at client side, the future changes are not going to be uploaded and saved on the server.
To avoid keeping the lock on files after closing the application, the FileManager unlocks automatically the edited files from the user when it is closed.

ns:warning.para: If the application crashes for some reasons, the FileManager cannot unlock the Files. The only way to unlock them is that the user reopens the application and unlocks the edited files properly.

sect1.title: Other Framework Dialogs
sect1.para: Beside the FileManager Rich Dialog you will find a collection of other rich dialogs that can be usefull in your applications. This documentation doesn't describes those rich dialogs in details. We just provide a short overview of them. Please read their Ivy Interfaces' documentation for more informations.

Those Rich dialogs can be devided in two groups:
The first Group contains two Rich Dialogs responsible for the Actions upon the Files. The major Rich Dialog in this Group is the DesktopHandler. This RDC is used as interface between the visual rich dialogs and the Java Classes developed to be able to perform actions on the files. This Rich Dialog was named "DesktopHandler" because it allows executing the methods contained in the java.awt.Desktop java Class. This DesktopHandler contains the other invisible Rich Dialog of this collection: the FileEditorChecker. This Rich Dialog is responsible for the persistency of the changes in a File edition. There should be no reason to have to implement directly this last rich dialog into your applications.
The Second Group contains 7 Rich Dialogs other than the FileManager:
The FileActionOptionPane: it should be used as Synchronous "popup" Window to perform an action (edit, print, download) on a given File. It contains a DesktopHandler to be able to edit or print the File.
The SimpleFileActionChooserPane: this Rich Dialog doesn't contain a DesktopHandler. He cannot perform the edit or print actions from itself. With this Rich Dialog you just choose upon "edit" or "print". It returns "edit" if the user presses on the "Edit" button or "print" if the user presses on the "Print" one. Else it returns "cancel". The Rich Dialog that calls this SimpleFileActionChooserPane should then contains a DesktopHandler to perform the choosed action.
The FileListChooserPane is just composed by a ComboBox. It should be inserted into a parent Rich Dialog. It is started with a server folder path and lists all the Files contained into this folder. It communicates with its parent Rich Dialog through a fired Event fileSelectionChanged@SUBSCRIBERS whenever the selection was changed. The object sent by this event is a DocumentOnServer. (ch.ivyteam.ivy.addons.filemanager.DocumentOnServer dataclass)
The SimpleFileChooserDialog: it contains a FileListChooserPane and returns the selected java.io.File. It contains also a DesktopHandler to be able to open the selected File. The user can then preview the File that he is about to select.
The FileNameDialog allows giving a Filename and optionally to choose an extension and a future place to store a created File on the server. This can be usefull in processes that create files and where the user should choose the name of the created file.
The FileUploadPreparer: in some processes a user has to choose some Files to upload on the server at a time when the place where to store the File is not known. With the FileUploadPreparer you can then select the Files to upload, and then upload them later by calling its uploadPreparedFiles method.
The FileListTable: This RDC is like a very simplified FileManager in the form of a RTable. It displays files contained into a folder on the File Server. The user can edit or delete the displayed files. He can also be used to upload some files. This RDC supports the files drag and drop from the client file system.
